Award.AwardTitle: A Study of Professional Learning Communities Amongst Secondary Science & Mathematics Teachers: Changes, Support Systems, Student Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This 52-month research project is designed to study the Partnership for Reform in Secondary Science and Mathematics (PRiSSM) professional development model that began in summer, 2004 with 45 lead teachers from 22 schools across six Washington state school districts. Mathematics and science teachers from feeder middle and high schools were supported in forming cross-district, cross-discipline professional learning communities (PLCs). The PLCs first developed a common vision of high quality teaching and learning, then collaboratively developed and pursued an inquiry question focused on instructional practice. Approximately 100 "Expanded Team" teachers will join PRiSSM in both 2005-2006 and 2006-2007 to establish school-based PLCs, led by the lead teachers and supported by PRiSSM facilitators. Teacher activity in this school university collaboration includes 1) participation in the year-long PLC collaborative inquiry and, 2) forty hours of summer coursework or other PD related to the area of inquiry.

The research on this model will contribute to the knowledge base on professional development through an empirical investigation of the model of supported teacher collaborative inquiry described above. Specifically, the research addresses how the interactions amongst PLC teachers contribute to new understandings about teaching, learning, and disciplinary content, and whether this translates into changes in classroom practice. A mixed methods research design will be used. Four PLCs will be purposely selected to provide in-depth understandings of the relationships amongst supported teacher collaborative inquiry, changes in classroom practices and improved student learning. Individual teacher case studies will be conducted inside these larger contexts. Teacher learning in relation to PD implementation will be determined with a variety of instruments including classroom observations, participant interviews, surveys and audio/video records of PLC meetings. Student achievement relative to national science and math content standards will be assessed through researcher-designed, classroom-based assessments as well as standardized state assessments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This five-year research on secondary science and mathematics teachers’ collaborative work to improve teaching and learning generated a number of important findings. We developed case studies of seven teacher groups known as Professional Learning Communities (PLCs). A PLC is a professional development (PD) model proliferating across the United States and other nations, and is seen as holding much potential for improving instruction. Based upon extensive data, we developed a detailed framework to describe the nature of the activities teachers engage in when undertaking a collaborative inquiry process. This framework relates specifically to phases of activity as teachers’ use information about student learning to study the impact of their instruction on students’ understandings and skills. These phases include data exploration, collection, analysis, and derivation of implications for teaching. We found that each of these phases was initially difficult for teachers, as they had little experience with data about student learning other than test results. Most groups spent their time determining or developing assessment tools, and then making sense of the results obtained from the assessment. Often they found that the assessment did not provide the information they desired. Most groups spent little time exploring what they might want to learn about student thinking, or what assessments might provide the most fruitful data. Most groups also spent little time deriving implications for future instruction based on the results of the assessment.

 We also developed a theoretical framework that can be used to describe, analyze, and support the work of PLCs. This framework has two dimensions related to a teacher group’s stance toward their collaborative work. One dimension, which we call the epistemological stance, addresses the perspective the group develops toward their use of information on student learning. This perspective ranges along a continuum from using predominantly summative assessments to prove that past instruction impacted student learning, to using assessments in a more formative and generative way to understand student ideas and inform future instruction. We found that groups adopting perspectives more like the latter were more productive in terms of making impactful changes to their instruction. The second dimension, which we call the dialogic stance, examines the nature of the conversation as teachers collaborate in the data phases described above. This dimension details the characteristics of teachers’ conversations when characterized by negotiation, which involves a willingness to question ideas, actions, and interpretations of results. Conversations characterized by strong negotiation (or an inquiry approach) tend to result in the development of a common understanding of subject matter goals and a critical perspective on the effectiveness of classroom activities. Conversations characterized by weak negotiation tend to be task-oriented and have little impact on individual teacher’s beliefs or understandings. Additionally, groups may not engage in negotiation at all, resulting in conversations that have little to do with collaborative inquiry.

Our research and that of others shows that productive PLC work is challenging to accomplish. These two frameworks allow researchers, school administrators, and PD providers to determine specific difficulties the teachers in a PLC might be experiencing. For those who provide professional support to teachers, they can use these frameworks to design elements of the PD activity and information. Given that significant time and money are used to support PLCs, our findings provide ideas that can help PLC participants attain the potential for instructional transformation that is envisioned.
